docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 OTHER POWERS OF COURT [ss 64–73] 2 of 2

heading.title: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
DIVISION 3 OTHER POWERS OF COURT [ss 64–73] 2 of 2

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
[s 67] s 67 Stay of proceedings (cf Act No 9 1973, section 156)

leg:heading.title: Stay of proceedings (cf Act No 9 1973, section 156)

p.text: Subject to rules of court, the court may at any time and from time to time, by order, stay any proceedings before it, either permanently or until a specified day.

level.toc-caption: [s 67.30] Contractual agreement as to forum

p.text: Contracts commonly include terms where the parties agree on a procedure for resolution of disputes. Depending on the nature of the contract, agreements of these kinds may involve an agreement to resort to the courts of a foreign jurisdiction: Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197; 79 ALR 9; 62 ALJR 389; BC8802600 (Greek island cruise — ticket condition submitting to Greek courts), an agreement to invoke arbitration procedures (see [275,445.5]–[275,445.25]) or an agreement to submit to the process of a private domestic tribunal: Webb v Confederation of Australian Motor Sport Ltd [2002] NSWSC 1075; BC200206763 (agreement to exhaust club’s internal procedures before commencing proceedings); Australian Football League v Carlton Football Club Ltd [1998] 2 VR 546 at 549–50 (agreement to submit to jurisdiction of football tribunal).

In all of these cases, the parties consensual agreement may be sufficient to justify a stay of proceedings commenced contrary to its terms: Huddart Parker Ltd v Ship Mill Hill (1950) 81 CLR 502 at 508; [1950] ALR 918; (1950) 24 ALJR 601; BC5000430 (salvage contract — submission to foreign jurisdiction — “strong bias” in favour of stay); Joy Manufacturing Co v A E Goodwin Ltd [1970] 1 NSWR 57 at 58–9; (1969) 91 WN (NSW) 671 (commercial licensing agreement — submission to arbitration — stay granted); The Eleftheria [1970] P 94 ; [1969] 2 All ER 641; [1969] 2 WLR 1073; [1969] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 237 (shipping contract — choice of law and exclusive jurisdiction clause); The El Amria [1981] Com LR 136; [1981] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 119 ; The Sennar [1985] 2 All ER 104; [1985] 1 WLR 490; [1985] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 521 .

However, the courts will be concerned to construe the true scope and effect of the contractual agreement. A preliminary question may be whether the supposed submission agreement actually forms part of the contract: Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197 at 224–229; 79 ALR 9; 62 ALJR 389; BC8802600 (ticket condition — not part of contract). In the case of agreements involving submission to the jurisdiction of domestic tribunals, the courts may imply restrictions of reasonableness and good faith on the scope of the agreement: Australian Football League v Carlton Football Club Ltd [1998] 2 VR 546 at 549–550; BC9703217 . In the case of agreements relating to foreign jurisdiction, a mere choice of foreign law does not imply a contractual restraint on proceedings in the local forum: Regie National des Usines Renault SA v Zhang (2002) 210 CLR 491; 187 ALR 1; [2002] HCA 10; BC200200802 at [81] . But, an agreement that a contract is to be subject to foreign jurisdiction may indicate both submission to the courts of that place and also that the foreign law is the proper law of the contract: Compagnie Tunisienne de Navigation SA v Compagnie d'Armement Maritime SA [1971] AC 572; [1970] 3 All ER 71; [1970] 3 WLR 389; [1970] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 99 ; Gem Plastics Pty Ltd v Satrex Maritime (Pty) Ltd (t/as South African Express Line) (NSWSC, Rolfe J, No 50013/95, 9 June 1995, unreported, BC9504735); not following S & W Berisford Plc v New Hampshire Insurance Co [1990] 2 QB 631; [1990] 2 All ER 321; [1990] 3 WLR 688; [1990] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 454 .

If the proper interpretation of the contract involves a restraint or submission of the kind described above, that circumstance will usually provide a strong justification for staying local proceedings brought contrary to the contractual agreement: Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197 at 231; 79 ALR 9; 62 ALJR 389; BC8802600 ; FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Ocean Marine Mutual Protection and Indemnity Assn Ltd (1997) 41 NSWLR 559 at 569B–E; BC9701134 (substantial grounds required for refusing a stay where parties have agreed on an exclusive jurisdiction provision); compare Akai Pty Ltd v People’s Insurance Co Ltd (1996) 188 CLR 418; 141 ALR 374; [1996] HCA 39; BC9606281 (statutory provision overriding contractual choice of law). Even in that case however, the local court retains a discretion to allow the proceedings to continue in the local forum. In exercising that discretion, the local courts may regard the contractual agreement as a relevant, but not determinative, consideration in the totality of the particular circumstances: Huddart Parker Ltd v Ship Mill Hill (1950) 81 CLR 502 at 508; [1950] ALR 918; (1950) 24 ALJR 601; BC5000430 (all events and witnesses in the local forum — stay refused); Leigh-Mardon Pty Ltd v PRC Inc (1993) 44 FCR 88 .

level.toc-caption: [s 67.35] Costs unpaid — dismissed proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 67.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 12.10, rr 12.4.

The rules provide for a stay where a second set of proceeding is commenced against the same defendant before costs have been paid in respect of any earlier dismissed proceedings involving the same cause of action: see rr 12.4 and 12.10 of the UCPR; Rice v Henley (1915) 32 WN (NSW) 54 ; Bowen v Hickey (1958) 78 WN (NSW) 820 at 822 ; Hutchinson v Nominal Defendant [1972] 1 NSWLR 443 at 448–9 . Where the rules do not specifically apply, such as where costs are unpaid in relation to prior proceedings in other courts or jurisdictions, the court may order a stay under the present section in order to secure payment of the outstanding costs: Byrnes v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 251; BC200602077 .

level.toc-caption: [s 67.40] Costs unpaid — interlocutory costs

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 67.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 36.11, rr 36.4, r 42.7.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 127, s 129(1).

Generally speaking, costs are not payable until the conclusion of proceedings unless the court makes a specific order or the general position is altered by Practice Directions that apply to the proceedings (for example because they have been entered in a special proceedings list maintained by a particular court). That general position appears to be reflected by r 42.7 of the UCPR, which provides that interlocutory costs are to be paid and dealt with in the same way as the general costs of the proceedings — subject to any contrary order. If the court does make a specific order for the payment of interlocutory costs, that order would generally be enforceable after entry: see s 127 of the CPA and rr 36.4 and 36.11 of the UCPR. However, even in such a case, s 129(1) of the CPA would confer power to stay enforcement of the costs order. But even if interlocutory costs have been ordered and remain unpaid, it would require a special case to justify a stay of proceedings where the costs of interlocutory proceedings have not been paid: Morton v Palmer (1882) 9 QBD 89 ; Re Wickham (1887) 35 Ch D 272 ; Graham v Sutton, Carden & Co [1897] 2 Ch 367 (suggestion that the defaulting party must be behaving vexatiously).

level.toc-caption: [s 67.45] Criminal proceedings

p.text: The Supreme Court may grant a stay in respect of criminal proceedings where it is necessary to prevent oppression or injustice. Undue delay in the commencement of proceedings may justify a stay if it is likely to significantly compromise the ability to determine the proceedings fairly and justly: R v Lawrence [1982] AC 510 at 517; [1981] 1 All ER 974 ; Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254; [1964] 2 WLR 1145 ; R v Humphrys [1977] AC 1 at 39, 45–6, 55 and 62–3 ; Mills v Cooper [1967] 2 QB 459 at 467; [1967] 2 All ER 100 ; R v Grays Justices; Ex parte Graham [1982] 1 QB 1239 at 1247; Barton v R (1980) 147 CLR 75; 32 ALR 449; BC8000111 ; Bosch v Ministry of Transport [1979] 1 NZLR 502 ; R v Derby Magistrates Court; Ex parte Brooks (1984) 80 Cr App R 164; R v McConnell (1985) 2 NSWLR 269 (delay in commencing proceedings); Cooke v Whitbread (1988) 14 NSWLR 51 . A stay may also be granted where there is a material irregularity relating to the bringing of the proceedings: R v Hartley [1978] 2 NZLR 199 (accused unlawfully brought within the jurisdiction); Moevao v Dept of Labour [1980] 1 NZLR 464 ; Miller v Ryan [1980] 1 NSWLR 93 at 109 ; R v Bow Street Magistrates; Ex parte Mackeson (1982) 75 Cr App R 24 (improper extradition); cf R v Plymouth Justices; Ex parte Driver [1986] 1 QB 95 at 123. There is no power to grant a stay merely because of the inherent complexity of the proceedings: R v Petroulias (2005) 62 NSWLR 663; [2005] NSWCCA 75; BC200501371 (difficulty of distinguishing between true issues of fact to be determined by the jury and questions of law to be determined by the judge).

level.toc-caption: [s 67.50] Foreign and local proceedings — inconvenient local forum

heading.title: Foreign and local proceedings — inconvenient local forum

p.text: The courts have long recognised, and attempted to provide a principled resolution of, the problems that arise when parties dispute that the local forum is the appropriate venue for the trial of the proceedings. The High Court decisions in Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197; 79 ALR 9; 62 ALJR 389; BC8802600 and Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538; 97 ALR 124; 65 ALJR 83; BC9002894 now settle the position for Australia: see [s 67.55] below. Before these decisions, the authorities did not reveal unanimity of approach in defining the principles to be applied. It is useful to have some understanding of the way in which judicial attitudes have developed.

One line of authority is illustrated by a number of cases: McHenry v Lewis (1882) 22 Ch D 397; 47 LT 549; 52 LJ Ch 325; 31 WR 305 ; Peruvian Guano Co v Bockwoldt (1883) 23 Ch D 225; [1881–5] All ER Rep 715; (1883) 48 LT 7; 52 LJ Ch 714 ; and was approved by the High Court in Maritime Insurance Co Ltd v Geelong Harbour Trust Cmrs (1908) 6 CLR 194; [1909] VLR 55a; [1908] HCA 37; BC0800041 . It is well summarised in the judgment of Scott LJ in St Pierre v South American Stores (Gath & Chaves) Ltd [1936]1 KB 382 at 398. There his Lordship said:

A mere balance of convenience is not a sufficient ground for depriving a plaintiff of the advantages of prosecuting his action in an English court if it is otherwise properly brought. The right of access to the King’s court must not be lightly refused.

In order to justify a stay, two conditions must be satisfied, one positive and the other negative: (a) the defendant must satisfy the court that the continuance of the action would work an injustice because it would be oppressive or vexatious to him or would be an abuse of the process of the court in some other way; and (b) the stay must not cause an injustice to the plaintiff. On both the burden of proof is on the defendant.

According to this line of authority, the discretion to grant a stay depended on evidence of oppression or injustice and is not exercised simply by an inquiry as to which is the more appropriate forum: see also Cope Allman (Aust) Ltd v Celermajer (1968) 11 FLR 488 at 492–3 ; Keenco v South Australia and Territory Air Service Ltd (1974) 8 SASR 216; 23 FLR 155 at 162–3 ; Masters Equipment Pty Ltd v Singapore Airlines Ltd (NSWSC, Sheppard J, 27 May 1976, unreported); The Courageous Coloctronis [1979] WAR 19 and In the Marriage of Tackach (1980) 6 Fam LR 282; 47 FLR 441; (1980) FLC 90–883 .

The other line of authority, which would confer a much wider discretion to stay proceedings, is illustrated by cases such as The Abidin Daver [1984] AC 398 at 411; [1984] 1 All ER 470 ; [1984] 2 WLR 196; [1984] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 339 and Spiliada Maritime Corp v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460; [1986] 3 All ER 843; [1986] 3 WLR 972; [1987] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 1 . Those cases determined that the appropriate test for stay applications of the present kind was virtually indistinguishable from the Scottish doctrine of forum non conveniens. (A discussion of that doctrine can be found in D W Robertson, “Forum non conveniens in America and England: ‘A rather fantastic fiction’” (1987) 103 LQR 398; “The emerging doctrine of forum non conveniens — a comparison of the Scottish, English and United States applications” (1985) 18 Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law 3.) Under such a test, where the local forum is not the natural forum, or one of the natural fora, and the plaintiff cannot demonstrate real personal or juridical advantage in the local forum, a court will grant a stay if the proceedings in the local forum would involve the defendant in substantial inconvenience and unnecessary expense: The Abidin Daver [1984] AC 398; [1984] 1 All ER 470 ; [1984] 2 WLR 196; [1984] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 339 ; Spiliada Maritime Corp v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460; [1986] 3 All ER 843; [1986] 3 WLR 972; [1987] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 1 ; MacShannon v Rockware Glass Ltd [1978] AC 795; [1978] 1 All ER 625; [1978] 2 WLR 362 ; The Atlantic Star v Bona Spes [1974] AC 436; [1973] 2 WLR 795; [1973] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 197 ; Amin Rasheed Shipping Corp v Kuwait Insurance Co [1984] AC 50; [1983] 2 All ER 884; [1983] 3 WLR 241; [1983] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 365 ; Chellaram v Chellaram [1985] Ch 409 (orders relating to the administration of a foreign trust; cf Ewing v Orr Ewing (1883) 9 App Cas 34 ).

Under the “inconvenient forum” criterion a defendant need not show either that continuation of the proceedings in the local forum would be oppressive or otherwise an abuse of process. Neither need the defendant show that proceedings have actually been commenced in the foreign jurisdiction: MacShannon v Rockware Glass Ltd [1978] AC 795; [1978] 1 All ER 625; [1978] 2 WLR 362 . If there were already concurrent foreign proceedings, that fact alone may be a powerful factor in favour of granting a stay: The Abidin Daver, above; de Dampierre v de Dampierre [1988] AC 92 at 108 ; unless there was a clear personal or juridical advantage available in the local forum to the party who has commenced the second set of proceedings: for example, Castanho v Brown & Root (UK) Ltd [1981] AC 557; [1981] 1 All ER 143; [1980] 3 WLR 991; [1981] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 113 and it would be unfair or unjust to deprive them of that advantage: de Dampierre v de Dampierre, above, at 102.

level.toc-caption: [s 67.55] Foreign and local proceedings — clearly inappropriate forum

heading.title: Foreign and local proceedings — clearly inappropriate forum

p.text: The High Court has expressly rejected the former “oppression” test and refrained from approving a mere balance of convenience test suggested in the English authorities: see Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538 at 556–8; 97 ALR 124; 65 ALJR 83; BC9002894 ; clarifying principles expressed in Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197; 79 ALR 9; 62 ALJR 389; BC8802600 . The High Court’s decisions adopt a “clearly inappropriate forum” test. That test will often produce results similar to the “balance of convenience” test: Voth at CLR 558. But where there are finely balanced considerations, and more than one forum may reasonably be regarded as appropriate, the test eschews a mere comparison between the competing fora and involves a focus on the extent to which the continuing conduct of the local proceedings should be regarded as inappropriate: Voth at CLR 559.
The “clearly inappropriate forum” test:

permits recognition of a plaintiff’s right to the exercise of a competent jurisdiction they have regularly invoked: Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay, above, at CLR 252; Voth at CLR 560 per Deane J;

does not treat either the apparent regularity of the proceedings, nor the fact that the substantive issues are governed by the local law, as determinative of the proper exercise of the stay discretion: Voth at CLR 559, 565–6;
is based on the power to dismiss or stay vexatious or oppressive proceedings;
requires more than the identification of the more appropriate forum;
requires restraint in the exercise of the stay power: Voth at CLR 554;

will typically involve an impressionistic comparison of the nature and extent of any legitimate advantage to the local plaintiff with the disadvantage to the defendant and whether it constitutes oppression in the relevant sense;

will involve consideration of the nature of the connection with the local forum and the various kinds of procedural, substantive and personal advantage or disadvantage involved in the local proceedings: Voth at CLR 565 — specifically referring to the discussion of the relevant factors in Spiliada Maritime Corp v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460 at 477–8 and 482–4; [1986] 3 All ER 843; [1986] 3 WLR 972; [1987] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 1 per Lord Goff.

The court’s task in applying the “clearly inappropriate forum” test is to assess whether the continuation of the local proceedings would be “vexatious and oppressive” or “clearly inappropriate” — in the sense of being seriously and unfairly burdensome or unjustifiably troubling: Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197 at 243, 247–8; 79 ALR 9; 62 ALJR 389; BC8802600 per Deane J (local contract — foreign shipping cruise — injury abroad — stay refused). This task will necessarily be influenced by the nature of the contentious issues, and particularly whether or not relevant remedies are only available in the foreign forum (see s 67.70). The assessment will involve impressionistic determination and is capable of being influenced by a wide range of considerations. Examples of situations in which those considerations have been held to justify the stay of proceedings include:

Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538; 97 ALR 124; 65 ALJR 83; BC9002894 (tort action — advice by foreign professional adviser — tax treatment of interest payments by foreign importer — stay granted);
Henry v Henry (1996) 185 CLR 571; 20 Fam LR 171; [1995] HCA 64; BC9601211 (foreign divorce proceedings — subsequent local divorce proceedings — stay granted);

CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345; 146 ALR 402; 71 ALJR 1143; BC9703378 (Australian corporate plaintiff in US proceedings — claim for damages under US statute — not available in local proceedings — defendant in US proceedings brought local proceedings involving related liability issues)

Global Partners Fund Ltd v Babcock & Brown Ltd (in liq) (2010) 267 ALR 144; [2010] NSWSC 270; BC201002078 (UK registered partnership — NSW proceedings by Cayman Island partner — Australian, USA and UK defendants — UK choice of law — concurrent UK proceedings by defendants).
Examples of situations where a stay of proceedings was refused include:

Puttick v Tenon Ltd (2008) 238 CLR 265; 250 ALR 582; [2008] HCA 54; BC200809900 (asbestos disease — cause of action governed by foreign law — local resident plaintiff — foreign law a question of fact in the local forum); (contrast the possible situation where the local forum precludes appeals on questions of fact: Studorp Ltd v Robinson [2012] NSWCA 382; BC201210606 at [13]–[19], [28])
Alstom Ltd v Sirakas [2010] NSWSC 669; BC201004252 at [49] and following (Australian service contract — transactions in Romania)

Fleming v Marshall (2011) 279 ALR 737; [2011] NSWCA 86; BC201101958 (alleged breach of retainer by US attorneys relating to settlement of US proceedings — foreign law dispute able to be resolved by reference under UCPR rr 6.44 and 20.14 — proceedings statute barred in US)

Murakami v Wiryadi (2010) 268 ALR 377; [2010] NSWCA 7; BC201000540 at [150]–[151] (resulting trust claim to Australian assets — US and Indonesian litigants — prior Indonesian matrimonial property settlement — no material dispute about content of Indonesian law)

level.toc-caption: [s 67.60] Ancillary concurrent foreign proceedings

p.text: Where local proceedings have been commenced and the jurisdiction of the domestic court is not challenged, the parties will ordinarily be required to deal with the proceedings in accordance with that court’s procedural rules. This does not preclude the parties from making interlocutory applications in a foreign court if they are made bona fide for the purpose of obtaining documents or other evidence for use in connection with the domestic proceedings: South Carolina Insurance Co v Assurantie Maatschappij (De Zeven Provincien) NV [1987] AC 24; [1986] 3 All ER 487 .

level.toc-caption: [s 67.65] Removal of stay

p.text: A stay of proceedings is not equivalent to a discontinuance or judgment for the plaintiff or defendant and may be removed if proper grounds are shown: Cooper v Williams [1963] 2 QB 567 at 580, 582 ; Lambert v Mainland Market Deliveries Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 826; [1977] 1 WLR 825 . Any judge has power to vary, discharge or suspend an interlocutory order made by any other judge including an order for stay if it is just and proper to do so: Hutchinson v Nominal Defendant [1972] 1 NSWLR 443 ; Douglas v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 126 .

level.toc-caption: [s 67.70] Restraint on prosecution of foreign proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 67.70] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 67.

heading.title: Restraint on prosecution of foreign proceedings

p.text: As noted in [s 67.20] , a CPA court has both the statutory power conferred by CPA s 67 and a general incidental power to control its own proceedings to ensure the due administration of justice. The occasions for the exercise of the discretion cannot be confined to closed categories of cases: McHenry v Lewis (1882) 22 Ch D 397 at 407–8; 47 LT 549; 52 LJ Ch 325; 31 WR 305 . They necessarily include a court’s power to stay its own proceedings where they have been commenced for an improper purpose. They may also include a power to restrain a party to proceedings in the court from pursuing related proceedings in another tribunal or forum. That power may be exercisable where the foreign proceedings (i) constitute an abuse of process, (ii) are being conducted for an improper purpose or (iii) would interfere with the conduct of the domestic proceedings: CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345; 146 ALR 402; [1997] HCA 33; BC9703378 ; CSR Ltd v New Zealand Insurance Co Ltd (1994) 36 NSWLR 138 ; Société Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale v Lee Kui Jak [1987] AC 871; [1987] 3 All ER 510; [1987] 3 WLR 59 (foreign proceedings); South Carolina Insurance Co v Assurantie Maatschappij (De Zeven Provincien) NV [1987] AC 24; [1986] 3 All ER 487; [1986] 3 WLR 398; [1986] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 317 ; Tszyu v Fightvision Pty Ltd (2001) 104 IR 225; [2001] NSWCA 103; BC200102125 (proceedings in another court in the same jurisdiction); Evers v Firth (1986) 10 NSWLR 22; BC8600974 (proceedings in another Australian state); Beecham (Aust) Pty Ltd v Roque Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 1 at 11; 89 FLR 238 (highly undesirable to restrain proceedings in another state court).

In addition a court may have a jurisdiction in equity to restrain foreign proceedings where those proceedings merely and wholly duplicate the substantive remedies available in the local proceedings: CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345 at 391–2 and 394; 146 ALR 402; BC9703378 .

A necessary starting point in the exercise of a local court’s power to restrain proceedings in another tribunal or forum is satisfaction that the local court should itself entertain the controversy between the parties. That satisfaction requires determination that the local court is not a “clearly inappropriate forum”: CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345 at 397–398; 146 ALR 402; [1997] HCA 33; BC9703378 .

The question whether the particular forum is a “clearly inappropriate forum” must take into account the totality of the issues disputed by the parties, not just the issues in the local proceedings: CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345 at 400–401; 146 ALR 402; [1997] HCA 33; BC9703378 . Where multiple proceedings between the same parties and relating to the same matter have been commenced within the jurisdiction, the commencement of the duplicate proceedings is presumptively vexatious, oppressive and improper: McHenry v Lewis, above; Williams v Hunt [1905] 1 KB 512 .

No similar presumption of impropriety applies where other proceedings have been commenced outside the jurisdiction. This is partly because of the potential for the foreign forum to provide substantive rights and remedies not available in the local forum: Société Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale v Lee Kui Jak [1987] AC 871; [1987] 3 All ER 510; [1987] 3 WLR 59 ; Peruvian Guano Co v Bockwoldt (1883) 23 Ch D 225; [1881–5] All ER Rep 715; (1883) 48 LT 7; 52 LJ Ch 714 . Indeed if the relief claimed in the foreign proceedings is not available in the local forum, the foreign proceedings cannot be regarded as vexatious or improper so as to justify the exercise of any equitable jurisdiction to restrain the foreign proceedings: CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345 at 395; 146 ALR 402; [1997] HCA 33; BC9703378 .

Even in the exercise of a court’s incidental power to control its own process, the fact that the foreign proceedings rely on a cause of action not maintainable in the jurisdiction will ordinarily make it difficult to establish that the local courts provide an appropriate forum, and afford strong grounds for refusing to restrain the foreign proceedings: British Airways Board v Laker Airways Ltd [1985] AC 58; [1984] 3 All ER 39; [1984] 3 WLR 413 (foreign cause of action not maintainable within the local forum, restraint refused); CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345 at 401; 146 ALR 402; [1997] HCA 33; BC9703378 (US anti trust damages not available in local forum — restrain refused); unless there are other grounds on which to impugn the foreign proceedings, such as where the party initiating the foreign proceedings has no relevant connection with the foreign jurisdiction, or has submitted to the local jurisdiction: Midland Bank Plc v Laker Airways Ltd [1986] QB 689; [1986] 1 All ER 526; [1986] 2 WLR 707 (US anti-trust litigation).

As to the special problems that may arise in connection with proceedings concerning property in which parties to proceedings in the Family Court may have an interest, see Reynolds v Reynolds [1977] 2 NSWLR 295; (1977) 3 Fam LR 11,529; 33 FLR 232; (1979) FLC ¶90–728 ; Williams v Williams [1979] 1 NSWLR 376; (1979) 5 Fam LR 137; 38 FLR 199; (1979) FLC ¶90-640 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 68] s 68 Attendance at court and production of documents and things to court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 64; Act No 11 1970, section 72; SCR Part 36, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Attendance at court and production of documents and things to court (cf Act No 9 1973, section 64; Act No 11 1970, section 72; SCR Part 36, rule 12)

p.text: Subject to rules of court, the court may, by subpoena or otherwise, order any person to do either or both of the following:
to attend court to be examined as a witness,
to produce any document or thing to the court.
See also section 77 of the Crimes (Administration of Sentences) Act 1999 and section 42 of the Children (Detention Centres) Act 1987 with respect to the attendance of persons detained in custody.

level.toc-caption: [s 68.5] Approved form

p.text: The approved form for an order for production is Form 29.

level.toc-caption: [s 68.10] Rules relating to the production of documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 68.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 17.5(4), r 21.5, r 33.13, r 33.2, r 34.1.

heading.title: Rules relating to the production of documents

p.text: Specific provisions of the rules relating to production of documents include:
UCPR r 34.1 (production of documents to a court or an examiner).

level.toc-caption: [s 68.15] Production in aid of Corporations proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 68.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 Pt 5.9, s 596D.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 34.1.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 68.

heading.title: Production in aid of Corporations proceedings

p.text: There is a long standing practice of using the general production power contained in the present section (or its predecessor provisions) to obtain production of documents in connection with examinations conducted under the provisions of the Corporations Act 2001 : Re BPTC Ltd (in liq) (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 713; 8 ACSR 533 at 538; 10 ACLC 1431 . The power complements the specific provisions in s 596D of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) (which relate to production by the person to be examined) and UCPR r 34.1 (which relate to production by parties to the proceedings). An order for production under the present rule may be directed to another individual or to a corporation: Onefone Australia Pty Ltd v One.Tel Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1188; BC200709049 at [15]–[16] per Barrett J citing Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36 at 52, 53; 56 ACSR 487; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 per Basten JA; In the matter of Teppanyaki Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 672; BC201204378 (order requiring a director to take steps to produce documents within the control of the company). However a production order under s 68 can only be made for the purposes of a particular examination and if the court is satisfied there is a sufficient connection between the order (ie the production of the particular documents) and the particular examination: Onefone Australia Pty Ltd v One.Tel Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1188; BC200709049 at [17]–[22] per Barrett J citing Re BPTC Ltd (No 5) (1993) 10 ACSR 758 at 762–763 per Bryson J; Re Leisure Developments (Qld) Pty Ltd; Ell v Palmer (2002) 41 ACSR 276 at 281–282; [2002] NSWSC 248; BC200201574 per Austin J; Onefone Australia Pty Ltd v One.Tel Ltd, above, at [4]–[5], per Barrett J. There is a discussion of the permissible purposes of an examination under Pt 5.9 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) in [15,785.10]–[15,785.30] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 69] s 69 Affidavits and witness statements may be read in advance of hearing

leg:heading.title: Affidavits and witness statements may be read in advance of hearing

p.text: Proceedings are not to be challenged, reviewed, quashed or called into question by reason only that the judicial officer or other person before whom the proceedings are being conducted has, prior to hearing, read any affidavit or witness statement that has been filed or lodged in the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [s 69.5] Reading affidavits and witness statements in advance

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 69.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

heading.title: Reading affidavits and witness statements in advance

p.text: The present section encourages the practice of judicial officers reading written evidence in advance. This practice has the potential to reduce the time taken to conduct proceedings in court, facilitate the determination of issues of admissibility, and thereby potentially reduce the costs of proceedings. Where directions are made which require the court being provided in advance with written evidence and objections those directions should be complied with because of their capacity to assist in the achievement of the overriding purpose in CPA s 56 : Re XYZ, Solicitor [2005] NSWSC 72; BC200500428 (non-compliance may attract sanctions against the legal practitioners responsible — notwithstanding settlement of the proceedings).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 70] s 70 Informal proof and admissions (cf Act No 52 1970, section 82)

leg:heading.title: Informal proof and admissions (cf Act No 52 1970, section 82)

p.text: At any stage of the proceedings, the court:
may, by order, dispense with the rules of evidence for proving any matter that is not bona fide in dispute, also with such rules of evidence as may give rise to expense or delay, and
without limiting the generality of paragraph (a), may, by order, dispense with the proof of handwriting, documents, the identity of parties or parcels of land, or of authority, and
may, by order, require any party (not being a person under legal incapacity) to make admissions with respect to any document or to any question of fact, and

in the case of a party’s refusal or neglect to make any admission required under paragraph (c), may, unless of the opinion that the refusal or neglect is reasonable, order that the costs of proof occasioned by the refusal or neglect are to be paid by the party.
An admission made under subsection (1)(c):
is to be for the purpose of the proceedings in which it is made and for no other purpose, and
is to be subject to all just exceptions, and
may, with the leave of the court, be amended or withdrawn.

level.toc-caption: [s 70.5] Application note

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 70.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 4.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.6, Sch 1.
This section does not apply to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court: see CPA s 4 , UCPR r 1.6 and Sch 1 .

level.toc-caption: [s 70.10] Not bona fide in dispute

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 70.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 70.

The power conferred by CPA s 70 is exercisable for the purpose of ensuring that the court is called upon to determine only questions that are bona fide in issue in the proceedings. Similar powers of informal proof exist in the rules of court of other jurisdictions. In some of these jurisdictions, it has been held that the power ought to be confined to proof of peripheral matters and that the power is not properly exercisable so as to permit informal proof of issues which may be critical to the outcome of the proceedings: H v Schering Chemicals Ltd [1983] 1 All ER 849; [1983] 1 WLR 143 ; Downs Irrigation Co-op Assn Ltd v National Bank of Australasia Ltd (No 2) [1983] 1 Qd R 475 ; Murine Eye Remedy Co v Eldred [1926] VLR 425 (informal proof of foreign incorporation); Meek v Guardian Assurance Co Ltd [1963] NSWR 1308 ; Pearce v Button (1986) 8 FCR 408; 65 ALR 83 at 90, 97, 102 . Note, however, the New South Wales provision is both in wider terms than the rules of court in some of these other jurisdictions, and is also included in the Act rather than in the Rules.

Accordingly, New South Wales cases evidence a willingness to permit CPA s 70 a wide operation and to permit the court a wide discretion to use the power conferred by the section whenever it considers that doing so would advance the interests of justice in the particular circumstances: Williamson v Mig Aero Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 27 June 1990, unreported, BC9002279); Ishac v David Securities Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Young J, 13 December 1991, 3511 of 1991, unreported, BC9101344); Coopers Brewery Ltd v Panfida Foods Ltd (1992) 26 NSWLR 738 ; Arnotts Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1990) 24 FCR 313; 97 ALR 555 at 604 ; Pearce v Button (1986) 8 FCR 408; 65 ALR 83 at 97 .

level.toc-caption: [s 70.15] Withdrawal of admissions

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 70.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 70(1)(c).

An admission made in accordance with the requirement under CPA s 70(1)(c) can only be withdrawn with the leave of the court. In the exercise of the discretion to grant leave to withdraw the court will obviously be concerned with the question of any prejudice that may be occasioned to the opposing party. However, even where there is no demonstrable prejudice it is still necessary to satisfy the court that the granting of leave is just in the circumstance. There are at least two competing considerations to be taken into account. On the one hand, too indulgent an approach to the granting of leave might tend to deprive the subsection of its practical utility. On the other hand, it will generally be proper to permit the withdrawal of an admission made as a result of a mistake or misapprehension of the true position: Coopers Brewery Ltd v Panfida Foods Ltd (1992) 26 NSWLR 738 , not following H Clark (Doncaster) Ltd v Wilkinson [1965] Ch 694 at 703; [1965] 1 All ER 934 . See further the additional note and examples in [17.2.5].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 71] s 71 Business in the absence of the public (cf Act No 52 1970, section 80)

leg:heading.title: Business in the absence of the public (cf Act No 52 1970, section 80)

p.text: Subject to any Act, the business of a court in relation to any proceedings may be conducted in the absence of the public in any of the following circumstances:
on the hearing of an interlocutory application, except while a witness is giving oral evidence,
if the presence of the public would defeat the ends of justice,
if the business concerns the guardianship, custody or maintenance of a minor,
if the proceedings are not before a jury and are formal or non-contentious,
if the business does not involve the appearance before the court of any person,
if, in proceedings in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court, the court thinks fit,
if the uniform rules so provide.

level.toc-caption: [s 71.5] Proceedings to be conducted in open court

heading.title: Proceedings to be conducted in open court

p.text: The limited permission granted by the present section emphasises the fundamental, though not inflexible, principle that courts ought conduct their hearings in public: Scott v Scott [1913] AC 417 at 439 ; McPherson v McPherson [1936] AC 177 ; R v Governor of Lewes Prison [1917] 2 KB 254 ; R v Hamilton (1930) 30 SR (NSW) 277 ; R v Local Government Board; Ex parte Arlidge [1914] 1 KB 160 at 187 ; Harvey v Harvey (1951) 68 WN (NSW) 241 at 242 ; R v Page [1976] 2 NSWLR 173 at 174; R v Chief Registrar, Friendly Societies; Ex parte New Cross Building Society [1984] QB 227; [1984] 2 All ER 27 at 31 ; Mirror Newspapers Ltd v Waller (1985) 1 NSWLR 1 . This fundamental principle is deeply rooted in the history of the common law: Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Jones (1985) 2 NSWLR 47 . It is regarded as an essential part of the character of courts of law. It is singularly important in promoting public confidence in judicial integrity and independence: Russell v Russell (1976) 134 CLR 495 at 520; 9 ALR 103; BC7600041 ; McPherson v McPherson [1936] AC 177 ; Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1983] 1 AC 280 at 316; [1982] 2 WLR 338 ; Tradestock Pty Ltd v TNT (Management) Pty Ltd (1983) 50 ALR 461 at 467 ; R v Wilson; Ex parte Jones [1969] SASR 405 at 413 ; Taylor v A-G [1975] 2 NZLR 675 at 678 ; Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Jones , above. Even if, consistent with either the statutory permissions, or the principles discussed in the following notes, proceedings are heard in closed court, it is quite inappropriate to seek to conceal, or to make orders preventing the disclosure of, the identity of the presiding judges: R v Felixstowe Justices; Ex parte Leigh [1987] 1 QB 582.

level.toc-caption: [s 71.10] Exceptions to the general requirement for public hearings — statutory

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 71.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 71.
(CTH) Crimes Act 1914 s 85B.
(CTH) Criminal Code Act 1995 s 93.2.
(NSW) Terrorism (Police Powers) Act 2002 s 26P.
(NSW) Witness Protection Act 1995 s 26.

heading.title: Exceptions to the general requirement for public hearings — statutory

p.text: The general principle may be excluded by statute or by the rules of court: Dickason v Dickason (1913) 17 CLR 50 at 51 ; John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW) (2000) 181 ALR 694; 158 FLR 81; [2000] NSWCA 198; BC200004288 (although the latter case suggests a difficulty in relying on state legislation to dispense with public hearings in courts exercising federal jurisdiction). CPA s 71 does permit courts to conduct proceedings in private in certain circumstances (including formal and non contentious matters, and aspects of interlocutory proceedings).
Commonwealth laws require courts exercising federal jurisdiction to conduct proceedings in private in some circumstances involving the interests of security or defence of the Commonwealth:
Crimes Act 1914 (Cth): Pt VII (official secrets and unlawful soundings) s 85B
Criminal Code Act 1995 (Cth): s 93.2 (interests of security or defence).
NSW laws require some civil proceedings, or parts of proceedings, to be conducted in the absence of the public:
Terrorism (Police Powers) Act 2002 (NSW): s 26P (proceeding in the Supreme Court relating to preventative detention orders or prohibited contact orders)
Witness Protection Act 1995: s 26 (any part of proceedings relating to the identity of a participant in a witness protection program).

level.toc-caption: [s 71.12] Exceptions to the general requirement for public hearings — rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 71.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCR Pt 65C r 3, SCR Pt 71A r 5, 47, 51, 63, 82, SCR Pt 78 rr 9, SCR Pt 80A rr 13A, 22, SCR Pt 82 r 3.

heading.title: Exceptions to the general requirement for public hearings — rules

p.text: The UCPR permits proceedings to be conducted “in the absence of the public” in the following situations:
UCPR r 56.4 (application for adoption order); and
UCPR r 56A.4 (application for parentage order).
The SCR permit private hearings in the following situations:
SCR Pt 65C r 3 (application for admission as legal practitioner — interstate applicant);
SCR Pt 71A r 5 (proceedings under Service and Execution of Process Act 1992);
SCR Pt 78 rr 9 , 47 , 51 , 63 , 82 (probate matters);
SCR Pt 80A rr 13A (remuneration of receiver), 22 (remuneration of provisional liquidator); and
SCR Pt 82 r 3 (appointment under Public Notaries Act).

level.toc-caption: [s 71.15] Exceptions to the general requirement for public hearings — discretionary

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 71.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 71(b).

heading.title: Exceptions to the general requirement for public hearings — discretionary

p.text: The general principle requiring judicial proceedings to be held in public permits discretionary exceptions where the "paramount object of securing that justice is done would really be rendered doubtful of attainment" by insistence on a public hearing: Scott v Scott [1913] AC 417 at 439 . This qualification on the general principle is substantially duplicated in CPA s 71(b) . The justification for this kind of exception is typically seen in two classes of cases, which are commonly heard in the absence of the public, namely:

cases where the jurisdiction of the court is parental and administrative, that is, proceedings relating to wards of court and persons of unsound mind: B v Medical Superintendent of Macquarie Hospital (1987) 10 NSWLR 440 ; see CPA s 71(c); and even in proceedings concerning the guardianship, custody or maintenance of a minor, as long as the identity of the child can be protected, the proceedings should be held in open court: Director-General, Dept of Community Services; Re Jules (2008) 40 Fam LR 122; [2008] NSWSC 1193; BC200809861 at [23]–[25] ; W v M [2009] NSWSC 1084; BC200909226 at [18] ;

cases where the litigation is as to a secret process: Scott v Scott [1913] AC 417 ; Andrew v Raeburn (1874) LR 9 Ch App 522; Badische Anilin und Soda Fabrik v Levinstein (1883) 24 Ch D 156 ; Mellor v Thompson (1886) 31 Ch D 55; Sandor v Curnow [1905] VLR 648 ; David Syme & Co Ltd v General Motors Holden Ltd [1984] 2 NSWLR 294 ; Amber Size & Chemical Co Ltd v Menzel [1913] 2 Ch 239 ; Arnotts Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1990) 24 FCR 313 at 317; 97 ALR 555 .

level.toc-caption: [s 71.20] Discretionary exceptions to the requirement of public hearing — further examples

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 71.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 63, s 71.
(NSW) Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010.

heading.title: Discretionary exceptions to the requirement of public hearing — further examples

p.text: The power to order private hearings, whether conferred by the specific provisions of s 71 or derived from the courts’ incidental powers, is not confined to matters of personal or commercial privacy of the kind referred to in the preceding note: Miller, Contempt of Court, p 212; Report on the Powers of Appeal Courts to Sit in Private and Restrictions upon Publicity in Domestic Proceedings, Cmnd 3149, para 6. The court may order evidence to be taken in private whenever it is of the opinion that justice would be defeated by insisting upon a public hearing: Moosbrugger v Moosbrugger (1913) 29 TLR 658; Cleland v Cleland (1913) 30 TLR 169; Norman v Mathews (1916) 85 LJKB 57. There is a tension between the generality of that power, and the basic principles of open justice. It is tension that is difficult to resolve with any verbal formula. In B v A-G [1967] P 119; [1965] 3 All ER 253 (a paternity suit) the Court, after noting that the question had been left unresolved in Scott v Scott [1913] AC 417; [1911–13] All ER Rep 1 , held that the mere likelihood a litigant would reasonably be deterred from pursuing their claim could not, consistent with the fundamental principle, justify a judge making an order for trial in the absence of the public. More recently the House of Lords (in case involving competition between rights of privacy and freedom of expression under the UK Human Rights Act 1998) held that it was inappropriate to prohibit publication of the names of parties to criminal proceedings in order to protect the privacy of their infant relations: Re S (A Child) (Identification: Restrictions on Publication) [2005] 1 AC 593; [2004] 4 All ER 683; [2004] 3 WLR 1129; [2004] UKHL 47 . A similar view was taken in Ashton v Pratt [2011] NSWSC 1092; BC201107346 under the Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 .

But general propositions highlighting the importance of the open administration of justice have to be applied with due regard to the circumstances of the particular case. There certainly are instances where reasonable apprehensions about the consequences of open proceedings have justified orders for hearings to be conducted in private.
For example, private hearings may be ordered:

on grounds of national security: R v Tillett; Ex parte Newton (1969) 14 FLR 101 at 127 ; A v Hayden (No 2) (1985) 56 ALR 82; 59 ALJR 6; BC8400488 ; Commonwealth v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Bryson J, No 2033/95, 26 June 1995, unreported, BC9504840) (restrictions on publication of evidence after conclusion of the hearing);

where a public hearing may involve adverse disclosure of financial details relating to a public company: Estates Property Investment Corp Ltd v Pooley (1975) 3 ACLR 256 ; R v Chief Registrar, Friendly Societies; Ex parte New Cross Building Society [1984] QB 227; [1984] 2 All ER 27 ; or any other trading enterprise, including one carried on by a trustee: Re Parker, Bagot's Executor & Trustee Co Ltd v King [1948] SASR 141 ; and

where a party has justifiable privacy interests that warrant protection: TK v Australian Red Cross Society [1989] 1 WAR 335 (orders made permitting persons who had contracted the AIDS virus to sue anonymously where it was established that they would otherwise be reasonably deterred from bringing proceedings); Re Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1403; BC201010640 at [19] (application for advice under s 63 of the Trustee Act in relation to settlement of proceedings); W v M [2009] NSWSC 1084; BC200909226 (prior injunction restraining publication of defamatory imputations); AMI Australia Holdings Pty Ltd v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1290; BC200910603 (proceedings to restrain publication in breach of confidence).

level.toc-caption: [s 71.25] Limited disclosure — protection of privacy

p.text: The principle of safeguarding the public interest in open justice is not inconsistent with protecting the legitimate privacy interests of parties and witnesses.

The Supreme Court, Local Court (see LC Practice Note 1 of 2008) and the Land and Environment Court (like other Australian courts) have adopted a formal policy on the anonymisation of personal information recorded in transcripts and judgments. The policy is directed at preventing identity theft, and protecting the interests of witnesses and accused persons in particular kinds of cases (eg where an accused person is under 18 or where a witness is the victim of sexual assault.)
The procedure for anonymising information involves:

use of automated substitution process to partially anonymise all information in number and address format (eg property number, telephone number, email address, fax number, other unique identifying numbers such as: bank account, tax file, medicare, credit card, car registration, driving license, passport, student identification);
judges being required to consider anonymising names and other information (eg dates of birth, anniversary dates)
judges being assisted to be aware of legislation prohibiting the identification of people in certain circumstances (eg sexual offenses).
A register of substitutions is to be maintained by the Reporting Services Branch.

In relation to protection of privacy generally see Supreme Court “Identity theft prevention and anonymisation policy” (March 2010) at http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/ agdbasev7wr/supremecourt/documents/pdf/policyidentity_theft_prevention.pdf .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 72] s 72 Court may prohibit disclosure of information

leg:heading.title: Court may prohibit disclosure of information

p.text: The Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 [301,000]–[301,375] consolidates the law relating to the making of non-publication and suppression orders by the courts.
[s 72 rep Act 106 of 2010 Sch 2.1, effective 1 July 2011]

level.toc-caption: [s 72.5] Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 72.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 ss 11, 12, 13, s 16, s 4, s 5, s 6, s 7.

heading.title: Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010

p.text: The Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 is set out at [60,000]–[60,375] (in Vol 2). Significant aspects of the legislation include the following:
s 4 : preservation of the inherent jurisdiction of courts to control their own proceedings (a power perhaps more accurately characterised as “incidental” rather than “inherent”; see [SCA s 23.25] )
s 5 : preservation of powers conferred by other specific statutory provisions
s 6 : a declaration that the “primary objective” for the administration of justice is “to safeguard the public interest in open justice”

s 7 : a general power to prohibit or restrict disclosure of the identity or parties or witnesses, or information concerning them, and power to suppress the disclosure of evidence and information about evidence in proceedings ss 8 and 9: prescriptive criteria (both substantive and procedural) for the exercise of the suppression power
ss 11 , 12 and 13 : provisions relating to the scope, duration and review of suppression orders
s 16 : the creation of an offence (punishable by a monetary penalty and/or imprisonment for a period of up to 12 months) for contravention of a suppression order.

level.toc-caption: [s 72.10] Prohibitions on the disclosure of evidence and information

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 72.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 s 4, s 6, s 7, s 8.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 80.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 72.

heading.title: Prohibitions on the disclosure of evidence and information

p.text: The Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 (CS&NPO Act) does not limit a court’s power to make suppression orders in the exercise of an inherent or incidental power to regulate its proceedings: CS&NPO Act s 4 .

In the exercise of the power conferred by CS&NPO Act s 7 a court must take into account that a primary objective of the administration of justice is to safeguard the public interest in open justice. This statement of the primary objective is a more explicit statement than was previously contained in either the Supreme Court Act 1970 s 80 or CPA s 72 . But the grounds on which a court may make an order under the CS&NPO Act are specifically stated in s 8 of the Act. Those grounds, include the criterion of necessity to prevent prejudice to the administration of justice and, in that respect, substantially repeat the previous statutory criterion in CPA s 72 . Section 8 also authorises suppression orders being made where the order is necessary to protect national or international security, the safety of any person, or to avoid undue distress or embarrassment to a witness in, or party to, sexual offence proceedings, or where the order is “otherwise necessary in the public interest and that interest “significantly outweighs the public interest in open justice”. The concept of “necessity” in this context conveys the idea of what is “reasonably necessary” rather than essentiality: R v Perish [2011] NSWSC 1102; BC201107143 at [42] .

The apparently more detailed provisions in s 8 of the CS&NPO Act, understood against the background of the “primary objective” in s 6 of the CS&NPO Act, suggest that the purpose of the Act was to discipline the circumstances in which suppression orders may be made: see Ashton v Pratt [2011] NSWSC 1092; BC201107346 at [8] . But the suppression power granted by CS&NPO Act s 7 applies to information “otherwise concerning” any party or witness. It is not limited to the identity of parties or witnesses, or even to evidence given in the proceedings: R v Debs [2011] NSWSC 1248 at [26] and [27] (order prohibiting pre-trail publication of information concerning an accused person’s other prior convictions). Neither is the power confined to making orders prohibiting disclosure by parties, witnesses or persons present in court: see [60,125.10].

See further the Court Suppression and Non-publication Orders Act 2010 especially ss 7 and 8 . In relation to protection of privacy generally see Supreme Court “Identity theft prevention and anonymisation policy” (March 2010) at http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/ agdbasev7wr/supremecourt/documents/pdf/policyidentity_theft_prevention.pdf .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 73] s 73 Power of court to determine questions about compromises and settlements

leg:heading.title: Power of court to determine questions about compromises and settlements

p.text: In any proceedings, the court:

has and may exercise jurisdiction to determine any question in dispute between the parties to the proceedings as to whether, and on what terms, the proceedings have been compromised or settled between them, and
may make such orders as it considers appropriate to give effect to any such determination.
This section does not limit the jurisdiction that the court may otherwise have in relation to the determination of any such question.

level.toc-caption: [s 73.5] Enforcement of settlements and compromises

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 73.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 73(2).

The jurisdiction conferred by the present section resolves the differing views that have been expressed as to whether a settlement agreement can be enforced in the original proceedings. In England the view had been taken that enforcement of the settlement generally requires new proceedings to be commenced (Green v Rozen [1955] 1 WLR 741 ; McCallum v Country Residences Ltd [1965] 2 All ER 264; [1965] 1 WLR 657 ; Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 37, para 388); unless the terms of the settlement agreement are embodied in an order and the proceedings have been stayed with liberty to apply: EF Phillips & Sons Ltd v Clarke [1970] Ch 322 . In Australia, a different view has been taken — founded on the power and duty of courts under, for example s 63 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 (NSW) (and its equivalents in other states) to grant all remedies to which any of the parties appears to be entitled so that as far as possible all matters in controversy may be finally determined and all multiplicity of proceedings avoided: Darling Downs Investments Pty Ltd v Ellwood (1988) 18 FCR 510; 80 ALR 203 . On this approach, in appropriate cases, a settlement agreement may be enforced on an application by motion in the original proceedings: Roberts v Gippsland Agricultural & Earthmoving Contracting Co Pty Ltd [1956] VLR 555 at 557, 562–7; [1957] ALR 71 . This is so, even though the settlement agreement may involve matters extraneous to the action, provided that the court is satisfied that the procedure is appropriate. Matters relevant to the court's consideration are the extent to which extraneous matters are involved, the nature of the issues to be determined, the extent to which questions of credibility are likely to arise, and whether pleadings and discovery may be desirable: General Credits (Finance) Pty Ltd v Fenton Lake Pty Ltd [1985] 2 Qd R 6 at 9–10 . See also Darling Downs Investments Pty Ltd v Ellwood (1988) 18 FCR 510; 80 ALR 203 ; McLaren v Schuit (1983) 33 SASR 139 . The enforcement of the settlement should not be dealt with in the original proceedings where there are substantial matters in controversy that go beyond the ambit of the proceedings as they were originally constituted, or where the interests of justice render the procedure inappropriate: Phillips v Walsh (1990) 20 NSWLR 206 at 210 . CPA s 73(2) probably preserves the discretion to require enforcement claims to be brought in separate proceedings in particular cases.
